entry.content:
HTB Season 10 Easy Machine

  • Easy
  • Linux
  • 20 points
  • URL: https://app.hackthebox.com/machines/WingData

Recon & Enumeration

Nmap

Looks like there is an http site hosted on the machine.

Vhosts Fuzzing

The website

  • The main website looks normal and has nothing interesting.
  • The http://ftp.wingdata.htb has wing ftb web client.
    • We can see the verion number on the login page.
    • Looking for any known vulnerabilities in this version, we find that it is vulnerable to Unauthenticated Remote Code Execution (RCE) (CVE 2025-47812).
      • We can find an exploit for this cve in exploit db : https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/52347

Gaining Initial Foothold

Understanding the CVE

Wing FTP Server versions prior to 7.4.4 are vulnerable to an unauthenticated remote code execution (RCE) flaw (CVE-2025-47812). This vulnerability arises from improper handling of NULL bytes in the ‘username’ parameter during login, leading to Lua code injection into session files. These maliciously crafted session files are subsequently executed when authenticated functionalities (e.g., /dir.html) are accessed, resulting in arbitrary command execution on the server with elevated privileges (root on Linux, SYSTEM on Windows)

Confirming the vulnerability

Let us use the exploit from exploitdb (https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/52347) and check if the website is vulnerable.

This confirms the exploit works for our machine.

Getting a revshell

  1. Lets start a netcat listener
  1. Send the revshell payload through rce.
  1. And a rev shell should be established

Getting into User account

The reverse shell got us into the machine as wingftp user, but we need to escalate our privilege into user account. Looking into the /home directory we see that there exists a user named wacky but we don’t have permission to view that user directory. Our working directory is /opt/wftpserver. Lets see if there are any interesting files what might have maybe exposed user details.

Finding the credentials

The user accounts of the wftp appears to be saved in the /opt/wftpserver/Data/1/users/ directory where we can see our user’s file wacky.xml as well. Looking into the file we see the password hash 32940defd3c3ef70a2dd44a5301ff984c4742f0baae76ff5b8783994f8a503ca. Trying to crack the hash doesn’t work. It appears to have been salted. Going through the settings.xml we find the salt.

Cracking the hash

We can use hashcat to bruteforce the hash as follows:

So the password to user account Wacky is !#7Blushing^*Bride5.

The user flag

Lets see if the password for ssh is also the same. Try to ssh into the machine:

And we are in. We can now get the user flag.

Privilege Escalation

sudo list

Lets see which commands our user can run without password.

Looks like we can run a python script as root without password. After reading the file, it appears to be vulnerable to CVE-2025-4138 which allows path traversal and arbitrary file write. We can use this vulnerability to write our ssh key and get access as root.

The exploit

The exploit script for this cve is:

Using the script

And finally grab the root flag.
entry.summary: HTB Seas

entry.title: SmileyCTF 2025 Crypto/SAAS Writeup
entry.content:
This is a writeup for the crypto/saas challenge of smileyCTF 2025.

The challenge is essentially a crypto challenge where we had to forge a signature for a given message by first reverse-engineering the cryptographic keys from the information provided.

The challenge provided the following Python code:

Analysis of the Cryptosystem/code

1. Key Generation

The script sets up an RSA-like cryptosystem. Learn more about RSA from here.

  • p & q: These are two 512-bit primes. A crucial detail is the condition p % 4 == 3. This means the primes must leave a remainder of 3 when divided by 4. Apparently these kind of numbers are special in cryptography and are known as Blum Primes. They make calculating modular square roots easy using the formula x^((p+1)/4) mod p.

  • n: This is the public modulus, the 1024-bit product of p and q. The security of the system relies on the fact that factoring n back into p and q is computationally infeasible.
    This is because even though n is extremely large, we can get it easily by multiplying p and q. But finding two prime factors (p and q) which when multiplying result to n is very hard because the best we can do is try all combinations of numbers which is not feasible for a number that is 1024 bits which is sth like 10 raised to power 300.

  • e: This is the standard public exponent 65537.

The Public Key is (n, e) but we only know e, and the Private Key is (p, q).

2. The Goal: Forging a Signature

The final part of the code presents the challenge:

The server gives us a random message(number) m and asks for a signature s. The signature is valid if pow(s,e,n)=m which mathematically equals to s^e ≡ m (mod n). This is the standard verification process for an RSA signature. To create s, we need to calculate the e-th root of m mod n. This is impossible without the private key, which requires factoring n.

3. The Vulnerability: The Square Root Oracle

The most important part of the code is the function f(x) which is provided to us as a service (maybe Saas refers to sq. root as service or sth like that)

This complex-looking function is a Square Root Oracle. Given an input l, it calculates one of its four modular square roots mod n . It does this by:

  1. Calculating a square root modulo p (using the Blum Prime trick).
  2. Calculating a square root modulo q.
  3. Combining them using the Chinese Remainder Theorem (CRT) to get a square root modulo n.

The choice([-1, 1]) ensures it randomly picks one of the four possible roots.

The Attack Plan

The entire attack focuses on abusing the sq. root service.

Stage 1: Discovering the Modulus n

The oracle guarantees that if we send it l, it will return a y such that y² ≡ l (mod n). This means y² - l is a multiple of n.

We can exploit this to find n:

  1. Ask the oracle for the square root of 1. Let the result be y1. We now know that M1 = y1² - 1 is a multiple of n.
  2. Ask the oracle for the square root of 4. Let the result be y2. We now know that M2 = y2² - 4 is also a multiple of n.
  3. Since M1 and M2 are both multiples of n, their Greatest Common Divisor (GCD) will be n itself (or a large multiple of it, but in practice, it’s n).

With this, we can recover the full modulus n.

Stage 2: Factoring n

Now that we have n, we can use the oracle in a different way to factor it. This is a classic cryptographic attack.

  1. Choose a random number x and compute its square l = x² % n. We now know one square root of l (it’s x!).
  2. Send l to the oracle and get its result, y.
  3. We now have two numbers, x and y, where x² ≡ y² (mod n). This means x² - y² ≡ 0 (mod n), which can be factored as (x - y)(x + y) ≡ 0 (mod n).
  4. There’s a 50% chance the oracle will return a “non-trivial” root, meaning y is not equal to x or -x (mod n). In this case, the prime factors p and q are split between the terms (x - y) and (x + y).
  5. This means that gcd(x - y, n) will reveal one of the prime factors, p. The other is simply q = n // p.

We can loop this process until we find a non-trivial root, which successfully factors n.

The Exploit

With p and q found, the rest is standard RSA. You can learn about it from here

  1. Calculate phi(n) = (p - 1) * (q - 1).
  2. Calculate the private exponent d = pow(e, -1, phi_n).
  3. Receive the message m from the server.
  4. Forge the signature s = pow(m, d, n).
  5. Send s to the server to get the flag.

The following script automates this entire process.

Final Solver Script

Disclaimer

I am just learning about Crypto and stuff and this writeup probably has errors. If u find any, please correct me 👍.

entry.title: THM Room Block
entry.content:
THM Medium Room

  • Challenge: https://tryhackme.com/room/blockroom

    Encryption? What encryption?

  • Background

    One of your junior system administrators forgot to deactivate two accounts from a pair of recently fired employees.
    We believe these employees used the credentials they were given in order to access some of the many private files from our server, but we need concrete proof.
    The junior system administrator only has a small network capture of the incident and a memory dump of the Local Security Authority Subsystem Service process.
    Fortunately, for your company, that is all you need.

  • medium

  • 120 min

Walkthrough

1. What is the username of the first person who accessed our server?

There are only two files in the archive: pcap file and memory dump. Open the pcap file to see authentication packets. Right after opening the file, we see an authentication packet on 11 no. with username right infront of us.

-> mrealman

2. What is the password of the user in question 1?

We will have to analyze the lsaas memory dump for this. Lets first understand what lsaas is.

LSASS is a critical component of the Windows operating system, responsible for enforcing security policies, handling authentication, and managing user logins. At the initial login, LSASS performs several key functions:

  • Caching credentials locally in memory>
  • Creating access tokens
  • Enforcing security policies
  • Writing to the Windows security log

Given its role, LSASS becomes a prime target for extracting credentials. By creating a memory dump of the LSASS process, we can analyze it offline to extract sensitive information.

To extract credentials we will be using a popular tool called mimikatz. You can download it from here (It will be flagged dangerous and you should be doing all this in a vm). After extracting, run the executable by double clicking it. Following window will appear:

Now run following command (pass full path of dump file):

Then following command. It will give a verbose output with all creds.


We need password of user: ‘mrealman’. We can use any of the 3 hashes shown. Lets try NTLM hash in an online rainbow table from here. A match was found. If a match was not found we would use hashcat. Keep the output of this for answering question 5.

-> Blockbuster1

3. What is the flag that the first user got access to?

Since we have the pcap file we can see what the user accessed. But the SMB traffic is all encrypted. We need to decrypt it. For this we need to give wireshark the NTLM password which we got from question 2. We need to go to Edit>Preferences>Protocols>NTLMSSP as shown in fig below:

But the packets are not decrypted yet. It appears that we need to check the Try to decrypt Kerberos blobs in Edit>Preferences>Protocols>KRB5 as shown in fig below:

Now the smb traffic of the user has been decrypted. We can see a files was downloaded from /clients. To download the file we need to go to File>Export Objects>SMB and Click save.

Opening the csv file, we see our flag.

-> THM{SmB_DeCrypTing_who_Could_Have_Th0ughT}

4. What is the username of the second person who accessed our server?

In the pcap file, when we scroll down, we can see another SMB Session Request in packet no. 82. The username is rigth there.

-> eshellstrop

5. What is the hash of the user in question 4?

We can just look for the creds of this user in output we got from mimikatz in question 2. It is probably asking for NTLM hash.

-> 3f29138a04aadc19214e9c04028bf381

6. What is the flag that the second user got access to?

The hash was not found in lookup tables online so we will use a different technique for this one. It was explained along with other 2 method neatly here.
For this method, we will use this script to create keytab file which we will load into wireshark to decrypt the packets. Download the script and open it in editor. We will have to manually add the NTLM hash in the script as shown below.

Then run the script using python and the output file should be generated. We will now pass this file to wireshark in Edit>Preferences>Protocols>KRB5 as shown below:

Now the packets should be decrypted. Now we can go to File>Export Objects>SMB and we should see a new file there.

We then save the file (\clients978.csv) and open it. Our flag should be right there.

-> THM{No_PasSw0Rd?_No_Pr0bl3m}

entry.title: THM Room Memory Forensics
entry.content:
THM Easy Room

  • Challenge: https://tryhackme.com/room/memoryforensics
  • Background:

    Perform memory forensics to find the flags

  • easy
  • 45 min

Walkthrough

We will need volatility3 to analyze the memory dump. Click the link to go to its github repo and install it from there. Looking at its documentation might also help.

Task 2: Login

The forensic investigator on-site has performed the initial forensic analysis of John’s computer and handed you the memory dump he generated on the computer. As the secondary forensic investigator, it is up to you to find all the required information in the memory dump.

  1. What is John’s password?

For extracting password, we need to use windows.hashdump plugin in volatility3 to list hashes first.

The exact command is:

We get following output:

We can see the NTLM hash of user John. We need to get the password from hash now. We can try online rainbow tables first then bruteforce using hashcat. Trying in https://hashes.com/en/decrypt/hash, we find a match.

-> charmander999

Task 3: Analysis

On arrival a picture was taken of the suspect’s machine, on it, you could see that John had a command prompt window open. The picture wasn’t very clear, sadly, and you could not see what John was doing in the command prompt window.

To complete your forensic timeline, you should also have a look at what other information you can find, when was the last time John turned off his computer?

  1. When was the machine last shutdown?

We need to determine the profile first using following command.

It returns output something like this with suggested profiles:

Now we can use the suggested profile and extract the last shutdown time using following command:

It returns following output:

-> 2020-12-27 22:50:12

  1. What did John write?

    We know John wrote something in console so we can simply look at console history using following command

It returns cmd prompt history which looks like as shown below. There is our answer hidden among these commands.

-> You_found_me

Task 4: TrueCrypt

A common task of forensic investigators is looking for hidden partitions and encrypted files, as suspicion arose when TrueCrypt was found on the suspect’s machine and an encrypted partition was found. The interrogation did not yield any success in getting the passphrase from the suspect, however, it may be present in the memory dump obtained from the suspect’s computer.

  1. What is the TrueCrypt passphrase?

    Lets get the profiles first.

It returns following output which has suggested profiles

Now we can use the truecryptpassphrase command to extract the truecrypt passphrase. The complete command is:

-> forgetmenot

entry.title: THM Room Investigating Windows
entry.content:
THM Easy Room

  • Challenge: https://tryhackme.com/room/investigatingwindows
  • Background:

    A windows machine has been hacked, its your job to go investigate this windows machine and find clues to what the hacker might have done.

  • easy
  • 45 min

Questions

  1. What’s the version and year of the windows machine?
    -> Windows Server 2016

Just went to settings and about PC to find the answer

  1. Which user logged in last?
    -> Administrator

Went to Event Viewer, then inside Windows Logs > Security logs. Filter by event ID 4624

  1. When did John log onto the system last?
    -> 03/02/2019 5:48:32 PM

Use cmd to find user details.

  1. What IP does the system connect to when it first starts?
    -> 10.34.2.3

To see startup task we need to look at HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE > SOFTWARE > Microsoft > Windows > CurrentVersion > Run, which contains startup instructions. There is following key there which contains required ip address.

  1. What two accounts had administrative privileges (other than the Administrator user)?
    -> Guest, Jenny

We can use following command to see all administrators.

  1. Whats the name of the scheduled task that is malicous.
    -> Clean file system

Opening Task Scheduler to view scheduled task, we can see following tasks. Looking through them the clean file system is running a suspicious powershell script.

  1. What file was the task trying to run daily?
    -> nc.ps1

  1. What port did this file listen locally for?
    -> 1348

  2. When did Jenny last logon?
    -> never

Used following cmd command to see Jenny account details

  1. At what date did the compromise take place?
    -> 03/02/2019

Looking back, the Jenny password was changed and the account was also probably created on this date and the malicious scheduled task was created on this day.

  1. During the compromise, at what time did Windows first assign special privileges to a new logon?
    -> 03/02/2019 4:04:49 PM

We know the compromise date so lets look at security events of that day. Lets filter the logs further using the Event ID 4672 which logs any special privileges assigned to a new logon. After filtering we can see following event in which loads of new perms were added to a account.

  1. What tool was used to get Windows passwords?
    -> mimikatz

Lets look at that TMP folder containing nc.ps1 file to see if it contains any clue. There are several files there. Looking in the txt files for clue we see that mim-out file is output of mimikatz. So, we can conclude that it was the tool used.

  1. What was the attackers external control and command servers IP?
    -> 76.32.97.132

Looking at the files in TMP folder, there was nothing useful. Lets look at hosts file to see they used dns poisoning to redirect legit site to C2. Opening C:\Windows\System32\drivers\etc\hosts that seems to be the case. The google.com domain has been redirected to a malicious ip.

  1. What was the extension name of the shell uploaded via the servers website?
    -> .jsp

Going to the C:\inetpub\wwwroot directory to see the files uploaded to website. And there are two files with .jsp extension. jsp seems to be some kind of java program for servers The gif file seems inherently harmless even if named shell.

  1. What was the last port the attacker opened?
    -> 1337

To see the opened port, we need to check windows firewall. Looking in Inbound Rules since we are looking for rules for incoming traffic. The first rule straight-up seems sus. Looking its details shows us that 1337 port was opened.

  1. Check for DNS poisoning, what site was targeted?
    -> google.com

We already found this while looking for C2 server.

entry.title: HTB Sherlock TrainingDay
entry.content:
HTB Easy Sherlock

  • Challenge: https://app.hackthebox.com/sherlocks/TrainingDay
  • Attachments:
    • URL: https://challenges-cdn.hackthebox.com/sherlocks/easy/TrainingDay.zip?u=1009643&p=mp&e=1743768663&t=1743761463&h=d0453236b1ccb3782d2f36f8b1b49f4024a600a1706d0a1cf919703e22b1b5d0
    • Password: hacktheblue
  • Background:

    A fresh new day, a well-rested cybersecurity professional—ready to learn something new after a chaotic week. Scrolling through challenges, they stumble upon TrainingDay, download the artifacts, and boom—three different binaries, each doing its own thing. Do they panic? Nope. This is exactly what they signed up for—some good old-fashioned reversing fun. If this sounds like you, what are you waiting for? Grab your debugger and dive in!

Walkthrough

This is a pretty lengthy CTF. Lets get started by extracting the zip file using the given password. There are 3 executables in the files.

  1. Lets pass the first executable through hash my file to get its sha256 sum.

  2. To get further info about the file, I passed it to Detect It Easy Tool which gave following output:

    This gave us the answer on IDE used, CPU architecture and if it was stripped or not.

  3. The next question asks for the full PDB path. For this, I used PE Bear. Opening the executable and looking at debug section in .text gave the PDB path we were asked. It also contained the windows username which was asked by next question.

  4. Next questions ask about arguments passed to function inside the executable. Lets open the executable in IDA and analyze it. The starting int __cdecl main (... indicated that the calling convention used is cdel.

We need to understand cdel convention before we can answer the next questions. In this convention, arguments are passed using the stack (LIFO - Last In, First Out). This means that if we imagine the stack as a pringles can, the end of the can will be our base pointer and each variable we add to the stack is like pringles being loaded in the can. When we need to eat we will take out the piece towards the mouth i.e the last one we put in, same happns here, when a variable is removed it will be the last one that was put.

1. Let's look at the code:

  1. So, the order of arguments is reversed. This means the last variable we passed, i.e., var_4, is the first argument on the stack and will be at the lowest address (esp). The second argument is the second-last one we passed, i.e., var_8, and its location is at higher address i.e. esp + 4. And the process goes on for the other arguments.

  2. The return value will be at eax cuz that’s what it is for.

  3. Now lets open the second file in IDA and analyze. The code looks like following:

It appears to be awfully same. Lets try cdecl as the convention, it isn’t. Trying fastcall as the convention, it appears to be it.

Since the code used fastcall convention we need to understand it. Fastcall api is similar to cdecl but in fastcall, the first two variables are directly stored in register and the remaining data is stored in stack normally. It also follows LIFO rule so the arguments are actually reversed in stack. Looking at the code, it appears to be a 32 bit system code so the first two variables (var_14 & var_10) must be stored in ecx and edx and other in the stack.

  1. For the variables stored in stack, the 3rd will be at the top i.e. esp and next one above it i.e esp+4 and then esp+8. For some reason the stack arguments were not reversed. This code itself looks weird cuz its stated as cdecl but is fastcall. Idk maybe comment if u know.

  2. Lets analyze the 3rd file now. Opening it in DIE we can see that it is designed for64 bit systems.

  3. Analyzing its code in IDA

It appears to be using fastcall convention.

In fastcall convention, the first few arguments in registers instead of pushing them onto the stack. But in modern x86_64 systems others are also stored in registers r8, r9,etc if available This is done to make it fast ig :) And it also follows LIFO principal similar to cdel so the order is reversed.

So, out first two and maybe more arguments are in registers and other in stack. Looking at the code, we can also see that, looking from bottom to top, these registered are used to store the arguments.

  1. For the 5th argument. first it is loaded into eax then stored in stack which can be seen below.
  1. Also, in fastcall convention, the return value of a function is stored in rax register.

Answers

  1. What is sha256sum hash of argumentT_baby_1.exe ?
    = dc6267608ddfcc5c80571ccd46475a03fb667baf8620d0e91c93ccacacf97ef6

  2. Can you find development enviroment of malware author (e.g:ide)?
    = visual studio

  3. What CPU architecture was argument_baby_1.exe compiled for ?
    = 32 bit

  4. Is argument_baby_1.exe a symbol-stripped binary?
    = false

  5. Retrieve the full PDB file path from the debug information of argument_baby_1.exe
    = C:\Users\HTB\Desktop\argument\Release\argument.pdb

  6. The malware author was using a Windows OS. What was the associated username?
    = HTB

  7. What calling convention is used in argument_baby_1.exe ?
    = cdecl

  8. How is the 1st argument passed to the function in argument_baby_1.exe?
    = esp

  9. How is the 2nd argument passed to the function in argument_baby_1.exe?
    = esp+4

  10. How is the 3rd argument passed to the function in argument_baby_1.exe?
    = esp+8

  11. How is the 4th argument passed to the function in argument_baby_1.exe?
    = esp+c

  12. How is the 5th argument passed to the function in argument_baby_1.exe?
    = esp+10

  13. Which CPU register holds the function’s return value in argument_baby_1.exe?
    = eax

  14. What calling convention is used in argument_baby_2.exe ?
    = fastcall

  15. How is the 1st argument passed to the function in argument_baby_2.exe?
    = ecx

  16. How is the 2nd argument passed to the function in argument_baby_2.exe?
    = edx

  17. How is the 3rd argument passed to the function in argument_baby_2.exe?
    = esp

  18. How is the 4th argument passed to the function in argument_baby_2.exe?
    = esp+4

  19. How is the 5th argument passed to the function in argument_baby_2.exe?
    = esp+8

  20. What CPU architecture was argument_baby_3.exe compiled for ?
    = 64 bit

  21. How is the 1st argument passed to the function in argument_baby_3.exe?
    = rcx

  22. How is the 2nd argument passed to the function in argument_baby_3.exe?
    = rdx

  23. How is the 3rd argument passed to the function in argument_baby_3.exe?
    = r8

  24. How is the 4th argument passed to the function in argument_baby_3.exe?
    = r9

  25. How is the 5th argument passed to the function in argument_baby_3.exe?
    = rsp+20

  26. In the case of argument_baby_3.exe, which CPU register stores the function’s return value?
    = rax

HTB Easy Sherlock

  • Chal

entry.title: HTB Sherlock Loggy
entry.content:
HTB Easy Sherlock

  • Challenge: https://app.hackthebox.com/sherlocks/Loggy
  • Attachments:
    • URL:https://challenges-cdn.hackthebox.com/sherlocks/easy/Loggy.zip?u=1009643&p=mp&e=1743098469&t=1743091269&h=c588b7a8260a2bf99f149b27a3f155f0cb90a67fc83f564cfbe51f337d0e6f81
    • Password: hacktheblue
  • Background:

    Janice from accounting is beside herself! She was contacted by the SOC to tell her that her work credentials were found on the dark web by the threat intel team. We managed to recover some files from her machine and sent them to the our REM analyst.

Walkthrough

This Sherlock is pretty easy. We don’t need to go too deep into the malware to answer the questions. We will use a VM (im using Flare VM). Download and extract the zip file using the given password. It contains few files and another zip file. The password for this zip file is in danger.txt. Use it to extract the zip file and there will be a .exe file we are supposed to analyze.

  1. After extracting all of the files, we can use Hash my files tool to find the SHA-256 hash of the binary.

  2. Lets use DIE (Detect it easy) tool to analyze the .exe file. We can see that the file is PE64 executable and the language it was written in was GO and the exact version number too.

  3. The next question asks us for github repo used for data exfiltration. We we have to filter out all of “github” strings from the binary and analyze them. We can use strings tool for windows to do this.

We can now go through the repos and see if any suspicious repo is present. We can see that a repo related to ftp is referenced. This is probably the one used for data exfiltration.

  1. There is other repo about screenshot. This probably means that the malware takes screenshot of the device. This also answers our question.

  2. Lets decompile the malware to reveal further details about it. We can use Ghidra to do this. Opening the executable in Code Browser in Ghidra,

  3. We will let the ghidra decompile the binary. In the meantime, the next question asks which function call suggests a file is written to disk. Lets look at the imports of the executable. It only imports KERNEL32.dll. Looking at the functions in the dll we find that writefile function is imported. This must be the answer.

  4. Now, we are asked what is the ftp domain and hacker’s creds. Looking through the main.main function in the decompiled code. At the end, inside a while(true) loop, it calls sendFilesViaFTP function.

Looking inside the function, there are the domain and login creds sitting there for us in plain text.

  1. To find which file is being written lets look at file handling function in the code. There’s a openfile() being called in line 117 few lines after the creds were initialized. Looking at the assembly code we can see the filename commented by Ghidra.

  2. The next question is asking us to look at the log and find what was the changed password. Looking at the log.txt file, it has keycodes and stuff. Looking closely we can see some letters and the username and password is just there.

  3. And the last question can be answered by just looking at the given images.

Answers

  1. What is the SHA-256 hash of this malware binary?
    = 6acd8a362def62034cbd011e6632ba5120196e2011c83dc6045fcb28b590457c

  2. What programming language (and version) is this malware written in?
    = golang 1.22.3

  3. There are multiple GitHub repos referenced in the static strings. Which GitHub repo would be most likely suggest the ability of this malware to exfiltrate data?
    = github.com/jlaffaye/ftp

  4. What dependency, expressed as a GitHub repo, supports Janice’s assertion that she thought she downloaded something that can just take screenshots?
    = github.com/kbinani/screenshot

  5. Which function call suggests that the malware produces a file after execution?
    = writefile

  6. You observe that the malware is exfiltrating data over FTP. What is the domain it is exfiltrating data to?
    = gotthem.htb

  7. What are the threat actor’s credentials?
    = NottaHacker:Cle@rtextP@ssword

  8. What file keeps getting written to disk?
    = keylog.txt

  9. When Janice changed her password, this was captured in a file. What is Janice’s username and password?
    = janice:Password123

  10. What app did Janice have open the last time she ran the “screenshot app”?
    = Solitaire
entry.summary:
HTB Easy Sherlock

  • Chal

entry.title: Setting up SIEM Lab Using Wazuh
entry.content:
This blog serves as an tutorial on basic installation of SIEM lab at home using Wazuh which also doubles as a XDR.

Wazuh is a free, open-source and lightweight Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) and Extended Detection and Response (XDR) software. It is simple to install and get started. To learn more about Wazuh, visit their website here.

Requirements for the setup (excluding host):

  • Storage: 70GB
  • Memory: 8 GB

Agents:

  • Windows 10 Home
  • Ubuntu 24.04.2 LTS Desktop

Server:

  • Ubuntu 24.04.2 LTS Server

At the end of this tutorial our wazuh dashboard will look like this:

1. Installing SIEM Server

We will use vmware workstation pro for setting up all of our devices. For SIEM server, we will do a minimal installation of ubuntu server and install wazuh in it.

Installing Ubuntu Server

Installation of ubuntu is pretty stratight-forward,

  1. Download iso from here and VMWare workstation Pro from here(or any other virtual machine platforms )
  2. Install the VMWare Workstation Pro (skip if you already have one).
  3. Create a vmware instance and add the downloaded iso. I used following provisioning:
    • 2 cores
    • 2 GB Memory
    • 30 GB Storage
  4. Start the vmware instance and install ubuntu with all default settings.
  5. Reboot the instance after installation and login using the username and password set during the installation.

Installing & Configure Wazuh

After installing ubuntu server, we will now install Wazuh. Wazuh is a lightweight and open-source SIEM Software.

Install Wazuh using following command.

After the installation, it will provide you with you username and password, note them down somewhere.

Now to access the dasboard, we will need our server’s ip. Use following command to get your ip address:

It will return following output:

Here on 2: after inet, 192.168.220.130 was my ip address. Opening it in a browser, outside my vm:

We can access the dashboard now. Login using the credentials we got after wazuh installation.

Configuring static ip

To prevent our wazuh server ip from changing whenever it is restarted, we need to set it as static ip.

  1. Open netplan config file:
  1. Paste the following and save (Ctrl+X->Y)

Now our server’s ip has ben set to 192.168.1.10 so we will use this to open dashboard and while setting up agents.

Setting up Workstations

We will connect two workstaions (one ubuntu and one windows) to our SIEM. First we will need these workstations. We will use VMs for our lab so I will do fresh installation of both machines.

Windows

  1. Download windows 10 iso from here

  2. Create a new VM instance, and install the downloaded Ubuntu iso using default settings. I used following provisions for my VM instance:

    • 2 CPU
    • 4 GB RAM
    • 25 GB Storage

  3. There are two methods to install the agent

    a. Open the Wazuh web page in browser and click add agent. Enter the details and paste the given commands in your windows powershell.

    b. Download Wazuh agent installer from here and run it. Then open powershell as admin and run following command

    Now edit the config file and add server ip and enrollement details as shown below:

  1. Now the windows machine should be shown in wazuh dashboard.

Ubuntu

  1. Download ubuntu iso from here.

  2. Create a new VM instance, and install the downloaded Ubuntu iso using default settings. I used following provisions for my VM instance:

    • 2 CPU
    • 4 GB RAM
    • 15 GB Storage

  3. Open the Wazuh web page in browser and click add agent. Enter the details and paste the given commands in your ubuntu terminal.

  4. Now you should see the agent in wazuh dashboard.
entry.summary:
This blog serves as an tutorial on basic installation of SIEM lab at home using Wazuh which also doubles as a XDR.

Wazuh is a fre
